subtitle: Space practice across time > mass practice all at once Sequence
questions:
When do players get opportunities to practice skills in your game?
How often do you want your player to practice key skills?
How many times will they be exposed to each key skill?
How much time is between the initial learning and the final “test” or implementation of knowledge?
How much time will it require for players to complete practicing?
What is the minimum required time for one set of practice?
description:
Leave some time in between practice/study/play sessions. 
Delayed reexposure/review can be very effective in learning new material. It is more damaging not to have a review at all than it is to have too much space between the initial exposure and the review.
examples:
Studying for 1 hour a day for 12 days > Cramming for a test for 12 hours the day before
Playing Duolingo for 7 hours on the plane on the way to Japan < Playing for 20 minutes every day for 2 weeks
Give students a review of course material the day after it is first presented < Review several weeks later
exampleGameDesc: Duolingo is a mobile app for learning languages. Duolingo encourages users to take a break in between lessons by providing incentives for “streaks” of practicing for multiple days in a row.

subtitle: Sequence instruction toward higher goals > no sequencing
questions:
What are all the skills in your game?
What order does the player encounter them in?
Could the sequence be adjusted to introduce more complex skills later?
How can the different levels of skills be presented to the players?
How can bigger practices be broken down into smaller pieces?
description: Structure content modularly; build upon prior concepts when introducing new concepts, and build towards a higher goal.
examples:
Teach a player to do a double-jump backflip in level 1 < teach jump in level 1,  doublejump in level 2, backflip in level 3, and double-jump backflip in level 4
Learn to draw contours and break objects down into shapes > draw a human figure in high fidelity
exampleGameDesc: Human Resource Machine is a puzzle game that teaches programming. The player controls tiny office workers with simple programming to perform tasks dictated by a cruel manager. Each level builds upon the one before it and incorporates previously learned commands, until at the end of the game the player has mastered the full language of commands.

subtitle: Students expect to be tested > no testing expected
questions:
What does the player need to know to succeed in your game?
Does the player feel that those KCs are necessary?
Can you make them feel more necessary?
How can players’ understanding be measured through the test?
description: Make it clear how key concepts being learned will be put to use later.
examples:
Tell your 6th grade class that there will be a quiz on this reading > tell them to do the reading because it will better them as a student
When teaching a player to perform a function, provide some examples of future tasks that this skill is needed to complete (“double jump: used for collecting butterflies”) > teach the function in a vacuum
exampleGameDesc: FreeCodeCamp is a free website that teaches users web development skills through a gamified curriculum of short “learn by doing” exercises. Each lesson begins with a few paragraphs of explanatory text and visuals, followed immediately by a coding problem. The user cannot complete the lesson without solving the problem. The consistent use of this pattern perpetuates the expectation that the information being learned in the introductory text is important, and will be put to use (tested on).

subtitle: Quiz for retrieval practice > study same material
questions:
Where do players exercise the skills they are learning in your game?
Do they have to exercise those skills repeatedly?
What are the core skills that must be tested before proceeding?
description: Re-expose players to core concepts by forcing them to recall material. Or pre-expose them to material they haven’t learned yet by asking them to make hypotheses about it.
examples:
Give a test summarizing the material > spend additional time studying the same material
Give a “pre-quiz” to expose students to upcoming math concepts and gauge progress > jump straight in
exampleGameDesc: Duolingo is a mobile app for learning languages. Duolingo challenges players to recall previously learned concepts by mixing questions from previous material into new lesson plans as the player progresses.

subtitle: Present lesson in learner-paced segments > as a continuous unit
questions:
What are all of the skills that a player needs to succeed in your game?
What are additional skills that a player needs to successfully apply those skills?
What are additional skills that a player needs to successfully apply THOSE skills?
How will the game adjust to players with different learning paces?
description:
Break material down into units that complement the pace of the player/learner, or even give them control over their own pace. 
Math is not a skill, it is actually a collection of related skills that people can have different mastery of.
examples:
Levels > One very long game
A Portuguese lesson on verbs used in cooking > a very long, continuous curriculum on all Portuguese verbs
exampleGameDesc: Elevate is a brain training game that is designed to boost productivity, earning power, and self-confidence in skills including math, reading, writing, speaking, and listening. It starts with a quick evaluation testing how players perform in different areas, and then suggest games that work the best for the current level. Players also need to reach a certain score to move to the next level.

subtitle: Provide feedback during learning > no feedback provided
questions:
What are all the channels the game is using to communicate status to the player?
How many of these relate to their application of target concepts?
How does a player know how they are doing?
What are some actions players can take after receiving a feedback?
How often should the feedback be provided?
description:
Provide feedback to the player on their performance as they are learning.
Timing of feedback may differ depending on the task being performed. Immediate feedback during play can be valuable to encourage or discourage behavior.
examples: A child does a calculation incorrectly, but the teacher lets it go because it is a difficult problem < the teacher points out the mistake as it happens
exampleGameDesc: JobPro: Get Dressed! Is a mobile game created by Simcoach Games that trains players in how to dress for a job interview. Players choose an outfit based on the role they are interviewing for, the atmosphere of the company, and various other factors. After the player makes their selection they receive detailed feedback about the outfit they chose and its compatibility with the position.

subtitle: Practice key prior skills before lesson > jump in
questions:
What prior skills are required for this specific lesson?
How can these prior skills be practiced effectively before the lesson? Multiple short practices or one long practice?
How well should the players be trained in those prior skills?
description: Provide some exposure to key concepts before the actual lesson.
examples:
Assign some readings before the lecture > jump straight in
Start choir with a warm-up that is in the same style as the song they group will learn that day 
Make players practice writing one sentence at a time before making them write a paragraph
exampleGameDesc: Coding for Carrots is a drag-and-drop coding game that tells a story of a rabbit searches for carrots by completing the block building activity. There is a trial round before every official game. It offers pretraining of the skills that the game wants to test, and it also helps to set an expectation of the difficulty level for the players.

subtitle: Worked examples + problem-solving practice > practice alone
questions:
How many or what type of worked examples can be provided for this lesson?
How can we make sure that players aren’t simply cloning the worked examples instead of solving the practices?
description:
Combine problem-solving practice with reviewing examples of solved problems that illustrate the steps taken to reach a solution.
Having students alternate between reviewing worked examples and solving similar problems on their own has been shown to be effective when teaching math, science, and technology.
examples:
A computer science student reviews code from a few similar projects while determining what approach she will take to do her homework assignment > she looks at the assignment and thinks about it really hard
An algebra textbook provides a worked example for each type of practice problem, using different variables and values > descriptive text and practice problems only

subtitle: Concrete to abstract representations > starting with abstract
questions:
What are some concrete/abstract representations of the concept?
What is the target audience and how will this affect the choice of concrete representations?
How are some ways of bridging the concrete and abstract representations?
description:
When explaining key concepts, use both abstract and concrete representations. Draw connections between the abstract and concrete examples, and highlight how they represent the same critical takeaways.
Concrete representations can be effective for inciting initial understanding of a concept, but may not support transferring that knowledge to other concepts. Abstract representations may be more difficult to grasp initially, but have shown to foster the ability to put the same knowledge to use in very different domains. Therefore some experts recommend concreteness fading: introduce a concept with concrete examples, and over time replace key components of that example with more abstract representations.
examples:
“Shelly needs 3 dozen eggs. X = the number of eggs she needs.” > “X = 3(12). “
Review a diagram of the circle of 5ths < Play through it on piano while following along on the diagram
Chocolate bar split into 4 equal pieces > ¼
exampleGameDesc: Ratio Rumble is a math game that helps players get familiar with ratios. Players connect “ingredient” tiles in quantities that match a given ratio. In this way players are exposed to a concrete representation of the ratio (for example 6 blue tiles and 4 green tiles) and must make the connection with the more abstract representation of the ratio (3:2) to succeed.

subtitle: Words include cues about organization > no organization cues
questions:
What are some segments of the lesson or practice that could be ambiguous to players?
What are some ways of explicitly stating the requirements?
How do we provide explicit instructions while keeping the players engaged? How can we give cues that won’t make the practices too easy or boring?
description:
Provide explicit instructions as needed to help the player anticipate where they should focus their attention.
 Verbal cues may accompany visuals to describe unfamiliar objects, or explain unobvious processes. Each text description should be near the visual element it describes.
examples:
A game with a tutorial and instructions > no text
A diagram illustrating the branches of government, with terms the player has never heard before < descriptive text throughout the graphic explains how they connect
exampleGameDesc:
Creature Capture is a strategy game published by the University of Washington Center for Game Science. It teaches young children to compare their game fraction values with those of the computer-controlled virals. 
To win the game, the player needs to pick a number that meets the requirement of the presented game cue.

subtitle: Integrate instructional components > no integration
Instruct at intermediate difficulty level > too hard or too easy
Cue student's prior knowledge > no prior knowledge cues
Immediate feedback on errors > delayed feedback
Intermix practice on different skills > block practice all at once
Practice applying new knowledge > no application
Practice with varied instances > similar instances
Compare multiple instances > only one instance
Graphics + verbal descriptions > verbal descriptions alone
Verbal descriptions presented in audio > in written form
Verbal descriptions in audio > both audio & written
Present description next to image element described > separated
Present audio & image element at the same time > separated
Extraneous words, pictures, sounds excluded > included
Real-world problems > abstract problems
Metacognition supported > no support for metacognition
Prompt for self-explanation > give explanation > no prompt
Time for reflection & questioning > instruction alone
Present incorrect or alternative perspective > only correct
Instruction relevant to student interests > not relevant
